facts.text: Civil Appeal No.4 of 1958 is an appeal by special leave from the decision dated September 19, 1956, of the Labour Appellate Tribunal of India, Calcutta, in Appeal No. Cal. 235/56.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No.4 of 1958. Appeal by special leave from the decision dated September 19, 1956, of the Labour Appellate Tribunal of India, Calcutta, in Appeal No. Cal. 235/56.

facts.text: The Judgment of the Court was delivered on October 16, 1959 by WANCHOO J.

anchor.surface_text: 1959. October 16. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by WANCHOO J.-This appeal is directed against the decision of the Labour Appellate Tribunal of India in an industrial matter.

facts.text: The appellant is a partnership concern carrying on business in the manufacture of pharmaceutical products.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant is a partnership companycern carrying on business in the manufacture of pharmaceutical products. There was a gratuity scheme in force in the appellant- companycern for a long time.

facts.text: There was a gratuity scheme in force in the appellant-concern for a long time.

anchor.surface_text: There was a gratuity scheme in force in the appellant- companycern for a long time. This scheme was modified by an award of the industrial tribunal dated August 18, 1952  hereinafter called the Award , and since then the modified scheme has been in force.

facts.text: The gratuity scheme was modified by an award of the industrial tribunal dated August 18, 1952, and the modified scheme has been in force since then.

anchor.surface_text: This scheme was modified by an award of the industrial tribunal dated August 18, 1952  hereinafter called the Award , and since then the modified scheme has been in force. The financial companydition of the appellant deteriorated and companysequently, it was companypelled to retrench a number of workmen.

facts.text: The financial condition of the appellant deteriorated and consequently it was compelled to retrench a number of workmen.

anchor.surface_text: The financial companydition of the appellant deteriorated and companysequently, it was companypelled to retrench a number of workmen. It, therefore, applied to the Appellate Tribunal under s. 22 of the Industrial -Disputes  Appellate Tribunal  Act  No. XLVIII of 1950 , for permission to retrench 89 workmen.

facts.text: The appellant applied to the Appellate Tribunal under s. 22 of the Industrial Disputes Appellate Tribunal Act No. XLVIII of 1950, for permission to retrench 89 workmen.

anchor.surface_text: It, therefore, applied to the Appellate Tribunal under s. 22 of the Industrial -Disputes  Appellate Tribunal  Act  No. XLVIII of 1950 , for permission to retrench 89 workmen. The Appellate Tribunal granted permission for retrenchment of 75 workmen only.

facts.text: The Appellate Tribunal granted permission for retrenchment of 75 workmen only.

anchor.surface_text: The Appellate Tribunal granted permission for retrenchment of 75 workmen only. Consequently, after obtaining such permission, the appellant retrenched the workmen and paid them companypensation as provided in s. 25F of the Industrial Disputes Act, 1947  hereinafter called the Act .

facts.text: After obtaining permission, the appellant retrenched the workmen and paid them compensation as provided in s. 25F of the Industrial Disputes Act, 1947.

anchor.surface_text: Consequently, after obtaining such permission, the appellant retrenched the workmen and paid them companypensation as provided in s. 25F of the Industrial Disputes Act, 1947  hereinafter called the Act . Thereupon a dispute was raised by the retrenched workmen through the union in existence in the appellant-concern for gratuity on retrenchment under the award.

facts.text: A dispute was raised by the retrenched workmen through the union for gratuity on retrenchment under the award.

anchor.surface_text: Thereupon a dispute was raised by the retrenched workmen through the union in existence in the appellant-concern for gratuity on retrenchment under the award. This dispute was referred to the Second Industrial Tribunal, West Bengal, on March 23, 1956, for adjudication in the following terms

facts.text: The dispute was referred to the Second Industrial Tribunal, West Bengal, on March 23, 1956, for adjudication on whether the seventy-five retrenched employees are entitled to gratuity in addition to retrenchment benefits.

anchor.surface_text: This dispute was referred to the Second Industrial Tribunal, West Bengal, on March 23, 1956, for adjudication in the following terms Whether the seventy-five retrenched employees  as per attached list  are entitled to gratuity in addition to retrenchment benefits ?

facts.text: The Industrial Tribunal concluded that the retrenched workmen were only entitled to relief as provided under s. 25F of the Act and not to any gratuity under the Award over and above the compensation payable under the Act.

anchor.surface_text: The Industrial Tribunal came to the companyclusion that the retrenched workmen were only entitled to relief as provided under s. 25F of the Act and were number entitled to any gratuity under the Award over and above the companypensation payable to them under the Act.

facts.text: The workmen appealed to the Appellate Tribunal, which allowed the appeal and held that the workmen were entitled to gratuity under the Award, as gratuity benefit therein was not a retrenchment benefit.

anchor.surface_text: Then followed an appeal by the workmen to the Appellate Tribunal which was allowed. The Appellate Tribunal held that the workmen were entitled to gratuity under the Award, as gratuity benefit therein was number a retrenchment benefit.

facts.text: The appellant applied for special leave to appeal, which was granted.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant then applied for special leave to appeal, which was granted and that is how the matter has companye up before us.

facts.text: The Award provides a gratuity scheme for cases of retrenchment or termination of service by the company for any reason other than misconduct or for cases of resignation with the consent of the management.

anchor.surface_text: We may therefore reproduce here the relevant part of the Award, which is in these terms The following gratuity scheme shalt be for cases of retrenchment or termination of service by the companypany for any reason other than misconduct or for cases of resignation with the companysent of the management.

facts.text: Gratuity under the Award is up to a maximum of 15 months basic pay, qualifying service one year, based on average of last 12 months basic pay.

anchor.surface_text: The gratuity will be paid up to a maximum of 15 months basic pay at the following rates. The period of service to qualify for the gratuity shall be one year. Consistently with the modification about the maximum qualifying service, the basic pay for the purpose of gratuity shall be the average of the last 12 months basic pay drawn by the workmen companycerned.

facts.text: No gratuity payable before completion of one year of service or to persons discharged for misconduct.

anchor.surface_text: Then followed the rates and it was also provided that numbergratuity would be payable before the companypletion of one year of service and that persons discharged for misconduct would number be entitled to any gratuity.

facts.text: In case of death of an employee, his widow or children or other dependents would be granted gratuity on the above basis.

anchor.surface_text: Finally, it was provided that in case of death of an employee, his widow or children or other dependents would be granted gratuity on the above basis.

facts.text: The Supreme Court holds that the gratuity under the Award on retrenchment is nothing more nor less than compensation on account of retrenchment.

anchor.surface_text: Now, under this Award, it is obvious that this payment on retrenchment though called gratuity is really numberhing more number less than companypensation on account of retrenchment.

facts.text: The appellant has already paid the compensation provided under s. 25F.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant has already paid the companypensation provided under s. 25F the workmen therefore are number entitled to anything more under the Award.

issues.text: Whether the seventy-five retrenched employees as per attached list are entitled to gratuity in addition to retrenchment benefits?

anchor.surface_text: Whether the seventy-five retrenched employees  as per attached list  are entitled to gratuity in addition to retrenchment benefits ? There was another matter included in the reference, but we are not concerned with that in the present appeal.

issues.text: whether the retrenched workmen are entitled under the Award to gratuity provided therein in addition to retrenchment benefit under s. 25F of the Act

anchor.surface_text: The sole question, therefore, for determination in this appeal is whether the retrenched workmen are entitled under the Award to gratuity provided therein in addition to retrenchment benefit under s. 25F of the Act. We may therefore reproduce here the relevant part of the Award, which is in these terms

issues.text: whether the payment on retrenchment though called gratuity is really nothing more nor less than compensation on account of retrenchment

anchor.surface_text: The name given to the payment is, however, not material and it is the nature of the payment that has to be looked into. Now, under this Award, it is obvious that this payment on retrenchment though called gratuity is really nothing more nor less than compensation on account of retrenchment.

issues.text: whether on a fair and reasonable construction of the Award, what the retrenched workman got is only compensation for retrenchment and not any amount by way of gratuity properly so called

anchor.surface_text: Further it is obvious from the terms of the Award that a retrenched workman could claim gratuity under the Award only on account of retrenchment and could not claim it under the other two conditions therein. In other words, on a fair and reasonable construction of the Award, what the retrenched workman got is only compensation for retrenchment and not any amount by way of gratuity properly so called.

issues.text: whether the Award provides payment not only for retrenchment but also for other termination of service which is specifically excepted from the definition of retrenchment under s. 2(oo)

anchor.surface_text: Retrenchment is defined under s. 2(oo) and means the termination by the employer of the service of a workman for any reason whatsoever, otherwise than as a punishment inflicted by way of disciplinary action, but does not include (a) voluntary retirement of the workman or (b) retirement of the workman on reaching the age of superannuation if the contract of employment between the employer and the workman concerned contains a stipulation in that behalf or (c) termination of the service of a workman on the ground of continued ill-health.

issues.text: whether the proviso to s. 25J(1) entitles a workman to retrenchment compensation under s. 25F in addition to gratuity under the Award or only protects higher rights without double payment

anchor.surface_text: Then comes s. 25J, sub-s. (1) whereof provides that the provisions of Chapter VA shall have effect notwithstanding anything inconsistent therewith contained in any other law including standing orders. There is, however, a proviso to sub-s. (1), which says that nothing contained in the Act shall have effect to derogate from any right which a workman has under any award for the time being in operation or any contract with the employer.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant has already paid the compensation provided under s. 25F the workmen therefore are not entitled to anything more under the Award.

holdings.text: under this Award, it is obvious that this payment on retrenchment though called gratuity is really nothing more nor less than compensation on account of retrenchment

anchor.surface_text: Now, under this Award, it is obvious that this payment on retrenchment though called gratuity is really nothing more nor less than compensation on account of retrenchment.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Name immaterial; substance determines nature as matching s.25F retrenchment compensation based on service period and pay average

holdings.text: on a fair and reasonable construction of the Award, what the retrenched workman got is only compensation for retrenchment and not any amount by way of gratuity properly so called

anchor.surface_text: Further it is obvious from the terms of the Award that a retrenched workman could claim gratuity under the Award only on account of retrenchment and could not claim it under the other two conditions therein. In other words, on a fair and reasonable construction of the Award, what the retrenched workman got is only compensation for retrenchment and not any amount by way of gratuity properly so called.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Retrenched workmen claim gratuity only on retrenchment account under Award terms, distinguishing from other cases

holdings.text: the Award provides payment not only for retrenchment as such but also for other termination of service which is specifically excepted from the definition of retrenchment

anchor.surface_text: Retrenchment is defined under s. 2(oo) and means the termination by the employer of the service of a workman for any reason whatsoever, otherwise than as a punishment inflicted by way of disciplinary action, but does not include (a) voluntary retirement of the workman or (b) retirement of the workman on reaching the age of superannuation if the contract of employment between the employer and the workman concerned contains a stipulation in that behalf or (c) termination of the service of a workman on the ground of continued ill-health. If this definition is compared with the provisions of the Award, it will be found that the Award provides payment not only for retrenchment as such but also for other termination of service which is specifically excepted from the definition of retrenchment.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Award terms cover retrenchment plus exclusions in s.2(oo) like resignation with consent and non-misconduct termination

holdings.text: provisions of Chapter VA have effect notwithstanding anything inconsistent in other law; proviso to s.25J(1) protects higher rights under awards but does not permit double payment of retrenchment compensation

anchor.surface_text: Then comes s. 25J, sub-s. (1) whereof provides that the provisions of Chapter VA shall have effect notwithstanding anything inconsistent therewith contained in any other law including standing orders. There is, however, a proviso to sub-s. (1), which says that nothing contained in the Act shall have effect to derogate from any right which a workman has under any award for the time being in operation or any contract with the employer.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Non-obstante clause overrides inconsistent provisions; proviso saves superior benefits but legislature intended no duplicate compensation

holdings.text: gratuity provided under the Award on retrenchment is nothing more nor less than retrenchment compensation under s.25F; workmen entitled only to whichever is more advantageous, not both
holdings.reasoning_summary: Substance analysis shows equivalence; s.25J allows better of two, but s.25F superior here; rejects Appellate Tribunal's distinction

holdings.text: retranched workmen are not entitled under the Award to gratuity provided therein in addition to retrenchment benefit under s. 25F of the Act

anchor.surface_text: The sole question, therefore, for determination in this appeal is whether the retrenched workmen are entitled under the Award to gratuity provided therein in addition to retrenchment benefit under s. 25F of the Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Already paid s.25F compensation satisfies Award gratuity obligation as they are identical in substance

holdings.text: the scheme of the Award providing for gratuity on retrenchment was exactly the same as compensation under s. 25F; provisions of s. 25F are better; entitled to s.25F only, not both
holdings.reasoning_summary: Direct comparison of rates and qualifications shows equivalence; s.25F provides better terms

holdings.text: appellant has already paid the compensation provided under s. 25F; the workmen therefore are not entitled to anything more under the Award

anchor.surface_text: The appellant has already paid the compensation provided under s. 25F the workmen therefore are not entitled to anything more under the Award.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Payment under s.25F fulfills all obligations under Award for retrenchment gratuity

anchor.surface_text: We therefore allow the appeal, set aside the decision of the Appellate Tribunal and restore that of the Industrial Tribunal in this matter.

outcome.relief_summary: Appeal allowed; Appellate Tribunal's decision set aside and Industrial Tribunal's decision restored; retrenched workmen held not entitled to gratuity under the Award in addition to compensation under s. 25F of the Act.
directions: Set aside the decision of the Appellate Tribunal
Restore the decision of the Industrial Tribunal

anchor.surface_text: Now, under this Award, it is obvious that this payment on retrenchment though called gratuity is really nothing more nor less than compensation on account of retrenchment.
We therefore allow the appeal, set aside the decision of the Appellate Tribunal and restore that of the Industrial Tribunal in this matter.

edges.explanation: Holding on construction of Award directly addresses the issue of what retrenched workman got under Award

anchor.surface_text: Further it is obvious from the terms of the Award that a retrenched workman could claim gratuity under the Award only on account of retrenchment and could not claim it under the other two conditions therein. In other words, on a fair and reasonable construction of the Award, what the retrenched workman got is only compensation for retrenchment and not any amount by way of gratuity properly so called.
We therefore allow the appeal, set aside the decision of the Appellate Tribunal and restore that of the Industrial Tribunal in this matter.

edges.explanation: h3 affirms that the Award covers other terminations excepted from s. 2(oo), directly addressing i5

anchor.surface_text: Retrenchment is defined under s. 2(oo) and means the termination by the employer of the service of a workman for any reason whatsoever, otherwise than as a punishment inflicted by way of disciplinary action, but does not include (a) voluntary retirement of the workman or (b) retirement of the workman on reaching the age of superannuation if the contract of employment between the employer and the workman concerned contains a stipulation in that behalf or (c) termination of the service of a workman on the ground of continued ill-health. If this definition is compared with the provisions of the Award, it will be found that the Award provides payment not only for retrenchment as such but also for other termination of service which is specifically excepted from the definition of retrenchment.
We therefore allow the appeal, set aside the decision of the Appellate Tribunal and restore that of the Industrial Tribunal in this matter.

anchor.surface_text: Then comes s. 25J, sub-s. (1) whereof provides that the provisions of Chapter VA shall have effect notwithstanding anything inconsistent therewith contained in any other law including standing orders. There is, however, a proviso to sub-s. (1), which says that nothing contained in the Act shall have effect to derogate from any right which a workman has under any award for the time being in operation or any contract with the employer.
We therefore allow the appeal, set aside the decision of the Appellate Tribunal and restore that of the Industrial Tribunal in this matter.
